title-group.article-title: Optimization of the processing parameters in melt blending of thermoplastic polyurethane and poly dimethyl siloxane rubber

article-meta.aff: Rubber Technology Centre, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, West Bengal, India

author-notes.corresp: Golok Bihari Nando, Rubber Technology Centre, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, West Bengal 721302, India Email: golokb@rtc.iitkgp.ernet.in

abstract.p: This article emphasizes the optimization of processing parameters required for the blending of polyether-based thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) and poly dimethyl siloxane (PDMS) rubber. Taguchi methodology was adapted as a statistical tool in the design of experiment to optimize processing conditions on the basis of tensile strength and impact strength for 50:50 blend of TPU and PDMS. L9 (33) orthogonal array strategy was utilized for conducting the experiments. The experimental data were transformed into signal-to-noise ratios, based on which each processing parameter has been optimized. Measure of confidence of the results has been studied using standard statistical technique of analysis of variance. From the results, the processing conditions have been optimized.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Design of new polymers through synthetic route for specific end-use applications has become an expensive and time-consuming process, as it involves several tedious and hazardous reaction steps. Therefore, the recent trend in the development of new material is by blending two or more polymers. This blending process has drawn considerable attention in the field of polymer engineering and science. Blending of two or more different polymers is an effective and inexpensive route for making new materials with specific end-use properties uncommon to either of the blend constituents. Properties of polymer blends are generally controlled by the properties of the individual components, the processing conditions, morphology developed during blending and the interaction between the blend constituents. 1
–5 The physical properties of immiscible polymer blends are found to be closely related to the size and shape of the deformable phases of the constituents. 6
–9 Nevertheless, immiscible polymer blends have potential advantages because of their distinct two-phase morphology, dispersed domain size, and technological properties. They can form a multiphase polymer system with a deformable minor phase. The morphological structures generated in situ during processing offer the potential to modify the dispersed phase through a wide range of size and shape of the same. The physical and morphological properties of these immiscible polymer blends depend not only on the shear stress, shear rate, and time of mixing but also on the processing temperature, chemical composition, viscosity ratio, and interfacial tension. These functions also play a significant role in the microstructure development of the immiscible polymer blends. 10
,11

During the past four decades, thermoplastic polyurethanes (TPUs) have received considerable attention both by the academia and by the industrial sectors. Because of its versatility, it is extensively used for high-performance applications requiring high impact strength, high abrasion resistance, solvent and oil resistance, good adhesion and so on. TPU has become a buzz word in every automobile, biomedical, footwear, wire and cable, coatings, and adhesive industries. 12
,13 In the recent past, extensive research on blending of TPU with the other polymers to achieve very interesting results for specific applications is ongoin. 14
–18 Blends of TPU with polyolefins, ethylene–propylene–diene elastomer have been investigated for technological, economical, and environmental reasons by many researchers. 19 –21

Design of experiments (DOEs) plays a very significant role in controlling time, thus reducing energy consumption and saving cost by limiting the number of experiments from a large number to a designated few by monitoring certain design parameters. Dr Genichi Taguchi evolved a simple statistical method based on the principles of the DOEs for optimizing different parameters in an experiment for improving the engineering productivity. Taguchi constructed a special set of orthogonal arrays to lay out the experiments. By combining the orthogonal latin arrays in a unique manner, he prepared new sets of orthogonal arrays to be used for a number of experimental set-ups. Orthogonal array accommodates different design factors simultaneously. 22 Signal-to-noise ratio (S/N ratio) and orthogonal arrays are the two major tools used in Taguchi’s robust design method. S/N ratio is a measure of robustness, which can be used to identify the control factor settings that minimize the effect of noise on the responses. The S/N ratio characteristics can be divided into three categories from the quality point of view. They are
Smaller is better, for example minimum shrinkage in a cast iron cylinder block casting. It is calculated from the following equation:
S N
= − 10 log
1 r
∑
i = 1
r
Y
i 2
Nominal is best. For example dimension of a part consistently achieved with modest variance. It is calculated from the following equation:
S N
= − 10 log
1 r
∑
i = 1
r
( Y i − M )
2
Larger is better. For example maximum life expected of a component. It is calculated from the following equation:
S N
= − 10 log
1 r
∑
i = 1
r
1
Y
i 2
where M is the average observed data, r is the number of observations, and Y is the observed data.

Taguchi’s methodology is a partial factorial design based on specially designed orthogonal arrays. This means Taguchi methodology is only a sample of the full experiments. Therefore, the analysis of partial experiments must include the analysis of the confidence that can be induced in the results. To provide a measure of confidence a standard statistical technique known as analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used. ANOVA does not directly analyze the data, it measures the variance of the data, and the confidence is measured from the variance. 23

In this article an attempt has been made to optimize the processing conditions such as temperature, rotor speed, and time of mixing for preparing immiscible blends of polyether-based TPU and PDMS rubber. A particular blend ratio has been chosen for carrying out the studies. The processing is carried out using Brabender plastograph®, and the processing conditions chosen per Taguchi’s L9 table. The optimization of processing parameters has been carried out on the basis of tensile and impact property data. Phase morphology studies of the blends have been done to support the findings.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: TEXIN® RxT85A, an aromatic polyether-based TPU supplied by Bayer Material Science LLC, USA, has been chosen as one of the blend constituents. Specific gravity of TPU is 1.12 and the melt flow index is 4 g/10 min at 190°C/8.7 kg. PDMS grade, silastic WC-50TM having specific gravity 1.17 procured from Dow Corning Inc. (Midland, MI, USA) has been chosen as the other blend constituents.

sec.title: Preparation of the blends
sec.p: A 50:50 blend of TPU-PDMS were prepared in the Brabender plastograph EC (digital 3.8-kW motor, a torque measuring range of 200 Nm and a speed range from 0.2 to 150 min−1) per Taguchi L9 table at different temperature range from 190 to 210°C, at different rotor speed starting from 60 to 100 rotation per minute (rpm) and at different time starting from 2 to 6 min. The mixed blends were sheeted out in a hydraulic compressor at a pressure of 7 MPa at the respective mixing temperature for 2 min to study the tensile and impact properties.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: The dumbbell specimens were punched out of the molded tensile sheets and tensile properties were measured per American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D 412 using a Hounsfield H25KS universal testing machine at ambient temperature at a crosshead speed of 500 m/min. Impact strength was determined using a tensile impact tester, CEAST (manufacturer company name of the impact tester) type 6545/0000 using a load of 7 kg per (Deutsches Institut für Normung) DIN53448.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy studies
sec.p: A JEOL-JSM-5800 scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used to study the blend morphology of TPU-PDMS blends. The samples were prepared by cryogenically fracturing the blends in liquid nitrogen and then extracting the PDMS rubber phase in toluene. Before examination, the fracture surfaces were dried in an oven at 70°C and then sputter-coated with a thin layer of gold in a vacuum chamber.

sec.title: Design of experiments
sec.p: DOE is a powerful analytical tool for modeling and analyzing the influence of control factors on performance output. Temperature of mixing, rotor speed in the Brabender plastograph, and time of mixing have been taken as the processing parameters. The impact of these three parameters, each at three levels, have been evaluated using L9 orthogonal design based on Taguchi methodology. In a conventional full factorial experiment it would require 33 = 27 runs to study three factors at three levels, whereas Taguchi’s factorial experiment approach reduces it to only 9 runs, offering a great advantage in terms of experimental time and cost. Tensile strength and impact strength of the blends are taken as the major property criteria to optimize the processing conditions. The analyses of the experimental data are carried out using the software MINITAB 15, specially used for DOEs. The experimental observations are transformed into S/N ratios. The S/N ratios for tensile strength and impact strength can be expressed as larger the better characteristics. The factors and their levels taken in the melt mixing process are provided in Table 1.

caption.p: Factors and their levels in the melt mixing process

sec.p: Table 2 depicts the array of L9 orthogonal table of Taguchi based on three factors at three levels of different processing parameters during the conditions of melt mixing.

caption.p: L9 orthogonal array per Taguchi methodology

sec.p: The addition of TPU into the Brabender plastograph has been done at 30 rpm. After the addition, the mixing chamber was closed and TPU was allowed to melt at 60 rpm. After the melting of TPU, the rotor speed was reduced to 30 rpm and the PDMS was added. Immediately after this, the mixing chamber was closed and the rotor speed was raised as given in Table 2. The mixing time also varied per Table 2. The torque versus time curves during the mixing process at three different temperatures (runs 1, 4, and 7) were recorded and presented in Figure 1. The molten mass was sheeted out in a cold roll and then compression molded at their respective processing temperatures in a compression molding hydraulic press at a pressure of 7 MPa for 3 min.

caption.p: (a), (b), and (c) are the torque versus time graphs during the melt mixing for the run 1 at 190°C, run 4 at 200°C, and run 7 at 210°C, respectively.

sec.title: Torque versus time during mixing
sec.p: Torque was monitored during the entire mixing process for all the nine experiments in the Brabender plastograph and only three representative torque versus time curves at three different temperatures are given in Figure 1. At higher temperature of melt mixing (200 and 210°C), the torque was very low as compared to that at 190°C. The torque generated by the neat TPU after melting in these trials shows interesting behavior. The viscosity of TPU at 200 and 210°C was lower than that at 190°C, and which is responsible for lower torque of the blends at higher temperatures. The change in viscosity of TPU with temperature is severe at its softening temperature of 180°C. This tendency of TPU plays a major role in the efficacy of melt mixing of TPU with other elastomers. Polymeric chains during melt mixing undergo shearing and breakdown leading to lower viscosity of the blends and different domain sizes of the dispersed phase. Figure 1(a) shows the torque versus time at 190°C. In this blend system, TPU has a very high strength as compared to PDMS. So a dispersed PDMS phase in a TPU matrix will be suitable to get good strength and impact properties. Any deviation from this, like the co-continuous morphology or the dispersed TPU phase in PDMS matrix, will lead to a drastic decrease in the mechanical strength of the blend. The effective shearing of polymeric chains of TPU and PDMS to obtain a finely dispersed morphology of PDMS phase to a TPU phase may be different at different processing conditions. This may lead to the different domain sized blend microstructure and phase morphology and lead to different technological properties.

sec.title: Tensile and impact properties
sec.p: The modulus at 100%, 200%, and 300% elongation, elongation at break, tensile strength, and tensile impact strength of the blends are given in Table 3.

The values of tensile and impact properties of the blends (Table 3) gave us a clear idea that the processing conditions have significant roles in TPU-PDMS blends. The tensile strength ranges from 2.02 to 5.07 MPa and the impact strength ranges from 2386 to 3946 J/m. The variation in these properties shows that optimization of processing conditions is significant in designing and in the preparation of TPU-PDMS blends. Primary analysis of the mechanical properties clearly gives an idea that the main factor that affects the mechanical properties is the processing temperature.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy studies
sec.p: SEM photomicrographs of the solvent-etched specimens of all the blends are shown in Figure 2(a–i). All the micrographs shown in Figure 2 are at ×3000 magnification with a scale of 5 µm. Figure 2(a–c) shows the photomicrographs of runs processed at 190°C. The etched portion showed the PDMS particles of microdomain size. From these figures, microdomains of PDMS rubber are clearly visible, which have been dispersed uniformly throughout the TPU continuous matrix. The domain sizes of PDMS rubber for run 1 (Figure 2a) lie in the range of 0.2–0.3 μm. The photomicrographs correspond to the runs at 190°C, which have the lowest PDMS domain size and have an almost dispersed morphology of PDMS phase in TPU matrix. This may be the reason for the higher mechanical properties shown by the blends melt mixed at 190°C (Table 3). This means the better dispersion of the PDMS in the continuous TPU matrix occurs at the lower temperature among the selected processing temperatures in this Taguchi methodology. On the other hand, PDMS domain sizes in the runs at the processing temperatures of 200 and 210°C (Figure 2d, i) show higher dimension as compared to runs at 190°C. In these photomicrographs, the PDMS is not uniformly dispersed in the TPU matrix. All these micrographs clearly show that relatively higher sized PDMS particles have been eluted off during etching and a significant amount of co-continuity among the TPU and PDMS phases. The larger domain size, uneven distribution and the co-continuity of PDMS in the TPU matrix may be responsible for the inferior properties shown by the blends processed at 200 and 210°C.

caption.p: Scanning electron micrographs of toluene-etched TPU-PDMS blends at a magnification of ×3000 and at a scale corresponding to 5 µm. a to i corresponds to the blend runs 1 to 9.

sec.p: The reason for the lower domain size of PDMS at 190°C can be explained using the time versus torque graphs shown in Figure 1. In Figure 1(a), the torque generated by TPU after melting is significantly higher than that of the other two runs in Figure 1(b) and (c). Thus, the experiments at 200 and 210°C does not experience effective shearing between PDMS and the molten TPU to get a dispersed morphology of PDMS in TPU matrix as compared to the runs at 190°C.

sec.title: Taguchi analysis of the TPU-PDMS blends
Analysis of S/N ratio
sec.p: The aim of any experiment is always to determine the highest possible S/N ratio for the results. A high value of S/N ratio implies that the signal is much higher than the random effects of the noise factors. Product design consistent with highest S/N ratio always yields the optimum quality with minimum variance. In the Taguchi method, the term ‘signal’ represents the desirable value (mean) for the output and the term ‘noise’ represents the undesirable value for the output. S/N ratio provides guidance for the selection of the optimum levels based on the least variation around the target parameter and also on the average value closest to the target. S/N ratio also gives objective comparison of two sets of experimental data with respect to variation around the target and deviation of the average value from the target value. Taguchi uses the S/N ratio to measure the quality characteristic deviating from the desired value. S/N ratios of processing parameters based on the analysis of tensile strength and impact strength are reported in Table 4. The category of higher is better S/N ratios was used to select optimum processing parameters. Figure 3(a) and (b) shows the main effect plot for S/N ratios on the tensile strength and impact strength properties of the blends, respectively.

caption.p: Main effect plot (data means) for sound-to-noise (S/N) ratios for the properties tensile strength (a) and impact strength (b).
Values of S/N ratios for tensile and impact strength properties of the blends

sec.p: Figure 3(a) represents the main effect plot for S/N ratios by taking tensile strength as the performance property. The S/N ratio values decrease from 13.937 to 8.143 as the temperature is increased from 190 to 210°C. The rank of temperature in the S/N ratio analysis is 1. Therefore, the optimum value of temperature to get higher tensile strength is considered to be 190°C. This clearly indicates that temperature is a major factor which has a significant role in the tensile strength of the blends of TPU and PDMS rubber. The effect of mixing time on S/N ratio shows a decreasing trend with increasing time. It reduces from 13.054 to 10.177. The rank for the mixing time in the S/N ratio analysis is 2. The rank of rotor speed in S/N ratio analysis is 3. Rotor speed (rank 3) does not have a significant effect on tensile strength as the S/N ratio vary only in the ranges of 11.256–11.552.

Figure 3(b) represents the main effect plot for S/N ratios by considering impact strength as the performance property. From this graph, one can identify temperature as the major factor that affects the impact strength as the rank of temperature in the S/N ratio analysis is 1. S/N ratios decrease from 71.61 to 68.64 as the temperature increases from 190 to 210°C. It is confirmed that melt mixing at 190°C gives the highest impact strength. Time of mixing ranks 2 in the S/N ratio analysis of the impact strength responses. The S/N ratio decreases from 71.13 to 69.77 as the time of mixing increases from 2 to 6 min. Similar to that of tensile strength, the mixing time of 2 min gives the highest S/N ratio in case of impact strength which is considered to be optimum. Rotor speed seems to be a minor factor that affects the impact strength as the S/N ratio varies between 70.47 and 70.19 as the speed increases from 60 to 100 rpm and the rank for rotor speed is 3 in S/N ratio evaluation.

From the S/N ratio analysis for tensile strength and impact strength, it is evident that the mixing temperature plays a major role in the performance properties. Thus, mixing temperature at 190°C has been considered the optimum processing temperature. Further a mixing time of 2 min may be considered the optimum time as almost all properties reach its highest at this time of mixing. The effect of rotor speed does not have much effect on the performance properties of the blends. However, rotor speed of 80 rpm may be selected as the optimum speed because it gives relatively higher S/N ratio in the tensile strength property data.

sec.title: Interaction of design parameters
sec.p: An interaction plot represents a single plot for two parameters and a matrix of plots for three or more parameters. It displays the levels of one parameter on the x axis and has a separate line for the means of each level of the other parameters. In this study, there are three design parameters. As a result, the interaction plot is a matrix of plots shown in Figures 4(a) and (b) for the tensile strength and impact strength properties, respectively.

caption.p: Interaction plots for design parameters (a) tensile strength and (b) impact strength.

sec.p: Perfectly parallel curves indicate no interaction between the parameters. Whereas any deviation from the parallel curves in the interaction plots indicate the higher degree of interaction between the parameters. Figure 4(a) and (b) represents a significant degree of interaction between the parameters because the interaction plots do not contain any parallel curves.

sec.title: Analysis of variance studies
sec.p: In order to understand the impact of various control factors on the response of experimental data, it is desirable to develop the ANOVA to find the significant factors. ANOVA allows analyzing the influence of each variable on the total variance of the results. The three-factor–three-level Taguchi design used in this study is an unbalanced design. General linear model is used for ANOVA for the unbalanced design.

For each designed parameter, the ANOVA provides the degree of freedom (d.f.), the sequential sums of squares (Seq SS), the adjusted (partial) sums of squares (Adj SS), the adjusted means squares (Adj MS), the F statistic from the adjusted means squares, and percentage contribution. Percentage contribution was calculated from the equation
where SSK is the sum of squares of parameter K and SST is total sum of squares. 24

Tables 5 and 6 show the results of ANOVA for tensile strength and impact strength, respectively. The factors such as temperature, rotor speed, and time of mixing are taken as fixed type. Analysis was performed with a level of significance of 5%, for example level of confidence 95%.

caption.p: Analysis of variance of processing parameters considering impact strength as the performance propertya

fn.p: Adj MS: adjusted means squares, Adj SS: adjusted (partial) sums of squares, d.f.: degrees of freedom, Seq SS: sequential sums of squares.

caption.p: Analysis of variance of processing parameters considering tensile strength as performance propertya

fn.p: Adj MS: adjusted means squares, Adj SS: adjusted (partial) sums of squares, d.f.: degrees of freedom, Seq SS: sequential sums of squares.

sec.p: Here the values of R2 in both the ANOVA of tensile strength and impact strength are 86.02% and 86.61% which imply that there is a significant fitting between general linear model and experimental data. It is also observed from the last column of Tables 5 and 6 that the percentage contribution of the design parameters on the response is in conformity with that predicted by the rank of parameters calculated from S/N ratios as shown in Table 4. The percentage contribution of errors is higher than that of percentage contribution of rotor speed. This means that the temperature and the time of mixing are the only two major factors in the processing conditions for the blends of TPU and PDMS in equal proportions.

sec.title: Confirmation of test results
sec.p: From S/N ratio analysis it may be concluded that the best temperature for processing is adjusted to be 190°C. The time of mixing also plays a significant role and mixing time of 2 min shall be taken as the optimum time for mixing. Though the effect of rotor speed is not significant, rotor speed of 80 rpm have been selected to get optimum performance properties. A TPU-PDMS blend in equal proportion has been prepared at these optimum processing conditions to confirm the statistical data and carried out its tensile strength and impact strength studies. The experimental and the predicted mean values of tensile strength and impact strength are given in Figure 5. The experimental values for tensile strength and impact strength are very much in tune with the predicted mean value.

caption.p: Predicted and experimental values of tensile and impact properties of the blend prepared at optimum processing conditions.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Optimum processing conditions for the melt processing of TPU and PDMS rubber have been investigated using Taguchi methodology. Three design parameters, namely the chamber temperature, the rotor speed, and the time of mixing were selected as variable parameters at three different levels for each. L9 orthogonal array was used for designing the experiments. S/N ratios for tensile strength, impact strength, and the ANOVA analysis data have been generated. From these analyses, the following conclusions are made.

list-item.p: The optimum processing parameters are found to be a temperature of 190°C, a rotor speed of 80 rpm, and a time of mixing of 2 min.

The degree of influence of the design parameters on the tensile strength and impact strength for the blends are in the order of temperature > time of mixing > rotor speed. The effect of temperature on the properties has been explained using the torque versus time plot for the mixing process and on the basis of scanning electron micrographs.
The predicted values of performance properties such as tensile strength and impact strength match with those of the experimental results.
